elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_neighborhoodIntro
elements.html:
The neighborhood where you live may play a role in a variety of health outcomes. Sharing details about your neighborhood may help researchers better understand the relationship between a person’s neighborhood and their overall well-being.

The following statements describe what your neighborhood might be like. Tell us how much you agree or disagree.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_neighborhoodGetsAlong
elements.title: People in my neighborhood generally get along with each other.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_neighborhoodSharesValues
elements.title: People in my neighborhood share the same values.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_neighborhoodIsNoisy
elements.title: My neighborhood is noisy.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_vandalismIsCommonInNeighborhood
elements.title: Vandalism is common in my neighborhood.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_neighborhoodIsClean
elements.title: My neighborhood is clean.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_crimeInNeighborhood
elements.title: There is a lot of crime in my neighborhood.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_drugUseInNeighborhood
elements.title: There is too much drug use in my neighborhood.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_troubleWithNeighbors
elements.title: I’m always having trouble with my neighbors.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_neighborhoodIsSafe
elements.title: My neighborhood is safe.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_whatIsInYourNeighborhoodIntro
elements.html: The next questions ask about what is in your neighborhood. Think about the area around your home that you can walk to in 10-15 minutes.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_neighborhoodHousing
elements.title: What is the main type of housing in your neighborhood?

choices.text: Townhouses, row house, apartments, or condos of 2-3 stories
Mix of single-family residences and townhouses, row houses, apartments, or condos
Apartments or condos of more than 12 stories

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_nearbyShops
elements.title: Many shops, stores, markets, or other places to buy things I need are within easy walking distance of my home. Would you say that you…

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_nearbyRecreation
elements.title: My neighborhood has several free or low-cost recreation facilities, such as parks, walking trails, bike paths, recreation centers, playgrounds, public swimming pools, etc. Would you say that you…

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_neighborhoodUnsafeAtNight
elements.title: The crime rate in my neighborhood makes it unsafe to go on walks at night. Would you say that you…

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_supportiveRelationshipsIntro
elements.html:
Supportive relationships may play a key role in helping people live healthy lives. Answering the following questions may help researchers learn more about the potential health benefits of supportive relationships.

People sometimes look to others for friendship, help, or other types of support. Choose the answer that best describes how often you can find support if you need it.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_someoneToHelpIfConfinedToBed
elements.title: Someone to help you if you were confined to bed

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_someoneToTakeToTheDoctor
elements.title: Someone to take you to the doctor if you need it

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_someoneToHaveAGoodTimeWith
elements.title: Someone to have a good time with

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_someoneToAskForAdvice
elements.title: Someone to turn to for suggestions about how to deal with a personal problem

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_someoneToLove
elements.title: Someone to love and make you feel wanted

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_relationshipsWithOthersIntro
elements.html: We would like to ask you some questions about your relationships with others. Choose the answer that is true for you.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_iAmOutgoing
elements.title: I am an outgoing person.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_iFeelIsolated
elements.title: I feel isolated from others.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_iCanFindCompanionship
elements.title: I can find companionship when I want it.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_iAmWithdrawnAndUnhappy
elements.title: I am unhappy being so withdrawn.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_peopleAreAroundMeButNotWithMe
elements.title: People are around me but not with me.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_discriminationIntro
elements.html:
People who experience discrimination may be at higher risk of negative health outcomes. Sharing your experiences with discrimination in everyday life and in healthcare settings may help researchers learn how to reduce negative health outcomes associated with discrimination.

The next statements describe how others may treat you. In your day-to-day life, how often do any of these happen to you?

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_youReceiveLessCourtesy
elements.title: You are treated with less courtesy than other people are.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_youReceiveLessRespect
elements.title: You are treated with less respect than other people are.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_youReceivePoorerService
elements.title: You receive poorer service than other people at restaurants or stores.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_peopleActAsIfYouAreNotSmart
elements.title: People act as if they think you are not smart.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_peopleActAsIfAfraidOfYou
elements.title: People act as if they are afraid of you.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_peopleActAsIfYouAreDishonest
elements.title: People act as if they think you are dishonest.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_peopleActAsIfTheyreBetterThanYou
elements.title: People act as if they’re better than you are.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_youAreInsulted
elements.title: You are called names or insulted.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_youAreThreatenedOrHarassed
elements.title: You are threatened or harassed.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_supposedReasonForTheseExperiences
elements.title: What do you think is the main reason for these experiences?

choices.text: Some other aspect of your physical appearance

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_howOthersTreatYouAtHealthcareProviderIntro
elements.html: The next statements describe how others may treat you. How often do any of these happen to you when you go to a doctor’s office or other health care provider?

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_youReceiveLessCourtesyAtHealthcareProvider
elements.title: You are treated with less courtesy than other people.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_youReceiveLessRespectAtHealthcareProvider
elements.title: You are treated with less respect than other people.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_youReceivePoorerServiceAtHealthcareProvider
elements.title: You receive poorer service than others.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_healthcareProviderActsAsIfYouAreNotSmart
elements.title: A doctor or nurse acts as if he or she thinks you are not smart.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_healthCareProviderActsAsIfBetterThanYou
elements.title: A doctor or nurse acts as if he or she is better than you.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_healthcareProviderNotListeningToYou
elements.title: You feel like a doctor or nurse is not listening to what you were saying.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_foodAndHousingIntro
elements.html:
The next set of questions asks about food and housing.

Lower food and housing security may increase the risk of negative health outcomes. Sharing your experiences about you or your family on this topic may help researchers learn how food and housing security influence health and well-being.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_worriedAboutBuyingFoodInLastYear
elements.title: Within the past 12 months, we worried whether our food would run out before we got money to buy more.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_timesMovedBetweenHomesInLastYear
elements.title: In the last 12 months, how many times have you or your family moved from one home to another?

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_problemsInLivingSpace
elements.title: Think about the place you live. Do you have problems with any of the following (check all that apply)?

choices.text: No or not working smoke detector

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_stressIntro
elements.html:
The amount of stress you feel can lead to negative health outcomes. Sharing your experiences may help researchers identify common triggers that induce stress in individuals and ways to provide support for individuals and communities.

The next questions ask you about your feelings and thoughts during the last month. Please choose how often you felt or thought a certain way.

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_howOftenUpsetByUnexpectedEventInLastMonth
elements.title: In the last month, how often have you been upset because of something that happened unexpectedly?

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_howOftenStressedInTheLastMonth
elements.title: In the last month, how often have you felt nervous and “stressed”?

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_howOftenConfidentToHandleProblemsInTheLastMonth
elements.title: In the last month, how often have you felt confident about your ability to handle your personal problems?

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_howOftenThingsGoingYourWayInTheLastMonth
elements.title: In the last month, how often have you felt that things were going your way?

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_howOftenUnableToCopeWithTasksInLastMonth
elements.title: In the last month, how often have you found that you could not cope with all the things that you had to do?

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_howOftenAngeredByThingsOutOfYourControlInLastMonth
elements.title: In the last month, how often have you been angered because of things that were outside of your control?

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_religionIntro
elements.html:
Elements of religion and spirituality can affect health outcomes. Sharing your beliefs and experiences may help researchers better understand the effects of religion and spirituality on health and well-being.

The next questions ask about your spiritual life. Some questions use the word "God." If it makes you more comfortable, you can replace that word with whatever you believe is spiritual, holy, or divine when answering.

How often do you experience the following:

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_feelHigherPowersPresence
elements.title: I feel God’s (or a higher power’s) presence

choices.text: I do not believe in God (or a higher power)

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_findComfortInReligion
elements.title: I find strength and comfort in my religion

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_feelInnerPeace
elements.title: I feel deep inner peace or harmony

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_wantToBeCloserToHigherPower
elements.title: I desire to be closer to or in union with God (or a higher power)

choices.text: I do not believe in God (or a higher power)

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_feelHigherPowersLove
elements.title: I feel God’s (or a higher power’s) love for me, directly or through others

choices.text: I do not believe in God (or a higher power)

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_howOftenAttendReligiousServices
elements.title: How often do you go to religious meetings or services?

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_languageIntro
elements.html:
Elements of religion and spirituality can affect health outcomes. Sharing your beliefs and experiences may help researchers better understand the effects of religion and spirituality on health and well-being.

The next questions ask about your spiritual life. Some questions use the word "God." If it makes you more comfortable, you can replace that word with whatever you believe is spiritual, holy, or divine when answering.

How often do you experience the following:

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_speakALanguageOtherThanEnglishAtHome
elements.title: Do you speak a language other than English at home?

elements.name: hd_hd_socialHealth_spokenEnglishProficiency
elements.title: Since you speak a language other than English at home, we are interested in your own thoughts about how well you speak English. Would you say you speak English…
